section_1_sacred_text.original_script: οἱ δὲ εἶπαν· Κορνήλιος ἑκατοντάρχης, ἀνὴρ δίκαιος καὶ φοβούμενος τὸν θεὸν μαρτυρούμενός τε ὑπὸ ὅλου τοῦ ἔθνους τῶν Ἰουδαίων, ἐχρηματίσθη ὑπὸ ἀγγέλου ἁγίου μεταπέμψασθαί σε εἰς τὸν οἶκον αὐτοῦ καὶ ἀκοῦσαι ῥήματα παρὰ σοῦ.
section_1_sacred_text.faithful_direct_translation: And they said: 'Cornelius, a centurion, a man righteous and fearing God, and being well-attested to by the whole nation of the Jews, was divinely instructed by a holy angel to summon you to his house and to hear words from you.'
section_1_sacred_text.standalone_english_translation: They replied, 'Cornelius, a centurion, is a righteous and God-fearing man, who is respected by all the Jewish people. A holy angel instructed him to send for you to come to his house so that he could hear a message from you.'
section_1_sacred_text.amplified_narrative_translation: The men responded with the following account: There is a Roman centurion named Cornelius, a man whose character is truly just and whose life is marked by a reverent fear of the one true God. In fact, he is held in such high regard that his good reputation is a matter of public testimony among the entire Jewish nation. This very man received a direct and specific command from a holy angel to formally summon you into his own home, for the express purpose of hearing the specific words of a message that you are to deliver.

literal_primary_filter: The verse records the direct speech of Cornelius's servants to the Apostle Peter.
Their statement provides a five-fold testimony to establish the credibility and divine origin of their mission.
First, they identify their master by name and rank: Cornelius, a centurion.
Second, they describe his personal character toward God and man: 'righteous and God-fearing.'
Third, they establish his public reputation: he is 'well-spoken of by the entire Jewish nation.'
Fourth, they state the divine impetus for their journey: he 'was divinely instructed by a holy angel.'
Fifth, they state the specific purpose of the command: to have Peter come and to 'hear words' from him.
prophetic_typology_and_intertextuality: Cornelius represents the fulfillment of the 'Type' of the faithful Gentile seeking God, promised throughout the Old Testament.
His inclusion is the 'Antitype' or realization of God's covenant promise to Abraham that 'in you all the families of the earth shall be blessed' (Genesis 12:3).
He embodies the prophetic hope of Isaiah that Gentiles would come to Israel's light and that God's salvation would reach to the end of the earth (Isaiah 49:6, Isaiah 60:3).

Cornelius, as a Roman centurion, parallels the faithful centurion in the Gospels whose faith amazed Jesus (Matthew 8:10), foreshadowing that many 'will come from east and west' to feast with the patriarchs.
The 'holy angel's' message continues a biblical pattern where God sends messengers to inaugurate new phases of His redemptive plan (Genesis 16:7, Exodus 3:2, Luke 1:11).

The necessity of hearing 'words' [ῥήματα] from Peter confirms the principle that salvation, even for the most devout, comes only through the specific, apostolic proclamation of the Gospel of Jesus Christ (Romans 10:14-17).
linguistic_mechanics_and_names: The name Κορνήλιος (Kornēlios) is Latin, identifying him with the prominent Roman *gens Cornelia*, immediately establishing his non-Jewish, Gentile identity.
The title ἑκατοντάρχης (hekatontarchēs, "centurion") denotes his role as a commander of approximately 80-100 soldiers and a vital NCO in the Roman military structure.
The adjective δίκαιος (dikaios, "righteous") describes his moral integrity and fair dealings with others, conforming to a standard of right conduct.

The phrase φοβούμενος τὸν θεὸν (phoboumenos ton theon, "fearing God") is a participle indicating a continuous state, used almost as a technical term for a class of Gentiles who worshipped the God of Israel without becoming full proselytes (Acts 13:16, 26).
The participle μαρτυρούμενός (martyroumenos, "being well-attested to") is in the present passive, signifying an ongoing, positive testimony given *about him* by others.

The verb ἐχρηματίσθη (echrēmatisthē, "was divinely instructed") is an aorist passive, indicating a specific, completed act of divine communication received by him. It is a term reserved for supernatural revelation (Matthew 2:12, Hebrews 11:7).

The command to ἀκοῦσαι ῥήματα (akousai rhēmata, "to hear words") emphasizes the need for specific, spoken content. The noun *rhēmata* often points to the very utterances themselves, distinct from *logos* (the overarching word or message).
literary_devices: The servants' speech is a masterpiece of diplomatic rhetoric, structured as a legal testimony to persuade Peter of the mission's legitimacy.
It presents a cumulative case, moving from Cornelius's personal identity to his private piety, his public reputation, and finally to the undeniable authority of an angelic command.
This logical progression serves to overcome Peter's deep-seated cultural and religious objections to entering a Gentile home (Acts 10:28).
numerical_and_gematria_significance: While this verse contains no numbers, the context states the angel appeared to Cornelius at the 'ninth hour' (Acts 10:3), the Jewish hour of afternoon prayer, signifying his devoutness within the framework of Jewish piety.
Peter's vision occurs the next day at the 'sixth hour' (Acts 10:9), the time of noon prayer, linking these two pivotal events to the established rhythms of seeking God.
historical_context_and_chronology: This event is dated conservatively to approximately A.D. 38-40.
This places it during the reign of the Roman Emperor Caligula (Gaius Caesar, A.D. 37-41).
It occurs after Saul's conversion (c. A.D. 34-35) but before the main thrust of his missionary journeys, making this a foundational event that officially opened the door for them.
The Jewish people at this time held a fierce commitment to ritual purity laws, which made table fellowship or lodging with a Gentile a source of defilement.
socio_political_matrix: Cornelius was a centurion in the 'Italian Cohort' (Acts 10:1), likely the *Cohors II Italica Civium Romanorum*, an auxiliary unit of Roman citizens stationed in Caesarea Maritima.
Caesarea was the Roman administrative capital of the province of Iudaea, making it a hub of Roman military and political power.
As an officer in an occupying army, a centurion would typically be viewed with suspicion or hostility by the local Jewish population.
Therefore, the testimony that he was respected by 'the whole nation of the Jews' is an extraordinary statement, highlighting his exceptional character and just conduct.
His actions would have been seen as a breach of Roman military decorum (seeking out a member of a subject people for religious instruction) and Peter's response a breach of Jewish Law.
geospatial_data_and_physical_geography: Cornelius was stationed in Caesarea Maritima, a major port city on the Mediterranean coast of modern Israel (32°30'N, 34°53'E; Altitude: Sea Level).
Peter was staying in Joppa (modern Jaffa), another ancient port city approximately 35 miles (55 km) south of Caesarea (32°03'N, 34°45'E; Altitude: ~10m).
The journey from Caesarea to Joppa would have taken Cornelius's men over a day on foot along the coastal plain, a major Roman road known as the Via Maris.

Peter was staying in the house of 'Simon, a tanner' (Acts 10:6), an occupation considered unclean, requiring his home to be near the sea for water and separated from the main populace, preconditioning Peter for a message about clean and unclean.
archaeological_confirmation: Extensive archaeological work at Caesarea Maritima has unearthed Herod's palace (where the Roman governors resided), a theatre, a hippodrome, and a sophisticated harbor, confirming its status as a major Roman center.

A limestone block discovered in the theatre at Caesarea in 1961 bears an inscription with the name '[PON]TIUS PILATUS' and '[PRAEF]ECTUS IUDAE[AE]', providing extra-biblical confirmation of the Roman administrative structure described in the New Testament.

While direct evidence for the *Cohors Italica* in Caesarea during this specific decade is debated, inscriptions confirm its presence in the province of Syria at a slightly later date, lending historical plausibility to the account.
aggregate_perspective_and_analogia_scrip: This verse crystallizes a pivotal moment in salvation history: the divinely-engineered breach of the wall between Jew and Gentile (Ephesians 2:14).
It demonstrates that human piety, righteousness, and good works, while pleasing to God and noted in heaven (Acts 10:4), are insufficient for salvation.
Salvation requires hearing and responding to the specific apostolic message—the *rhēmata*—concerning the person and work of Jesus Christ.
God honors the sincere seeker by sovereignly arranging circumstances for them to hear the Gospel.
The testimony of Cornelius's servants shows that a believer's public reputation for integrity (δίκαιος) among non-believers can be a powerful tool used by God to open doors for the Gospel.

Peter's willingness to go, prompted by this testimony and his own vision, affirms that God's plan supersedes human tradition and prejudice, fulfilling the prophecy that God would pour out His Spirit 'on all flesh' (Joel 2:28, Acts 2:17).

conclusion: Your personal character and public reputation are your most powerful witnesses. Live a righteous, God-fearing life with such integrity that even those outside the faith must respect you. This builds a bridge of credibility for the Gospel.

Recognize that sincere piety and good morality in others are not substitutes for the Gospel. Like Cornelius, the most devout person still needs to hear the specific words about Jesus Christ to be saved. Never assume good people are saved people.

Be prepared for God to send you across cultural, social, or personal boundaries you find uncomfortable. The command to share the Gospel, validated by the character of the seeker and the confirmation of the Holy Spirit, must override personal prejudice.

Actively listen for God's divine instructions. Just as Cornelius was instructed and Peter was prepared, expect God to orchestrate encounters and be ready to obey when He clearly directs you to speak His words to a specific person.
